current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to make improvements to the Medicare hospital
			 readmissions reduction program.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Hospital Readmissions Program Accuracy and Accountability Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Hospital Readmissions Program Accuracy and Accountability Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: makes the following findings:

text.#text:
Eliminating avoidable hospital readmissions should be a core tenet of public and private efforts to
			 improve quality of care and reduce health care expenditures.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
should accurately reflect the quality of care provided by specific hospitals and
			 providers, and such measures should never lower outcome or quality
			 expectations for certain cohorts of hospitals and providers.

text.#text:
There are numerous socioeconomic conditions that impact health outcomes and the Medicare hospital
			 readmission reduction program is one of many Federal outcome performance
			 programs that fails to accurately adjust for these influences.

Holding all other factors constant, socioeconomic conditions, such as poverty, low levels of
			 literacy, limited English proficiency, minimal social support, poor living
			 conditions, and limited community resources, likely have direct and
			 significant
			 impacts on avoidable hospital readmissions.

The Medicare hospital readmission reduction program includes risk adjustment for clinical
			 variables, such as comorbidity and severity of illness, because hospitals
			 should not be penalized for the
			 effects of these uncontrollable factors. Socioeconomic factors can
			 influence readmissions to an equal or greater degree than these clinical
			 factors and the Medicare hospital readmissions reduction program will more
			 accurately measure quality of care once risk adjustment for socioeconomic
			 status is implemented.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the National Quality Forum, and other
			 independent experts has provided compelling evidence that failing to
			 adjust for socioeconomic status in the Medicare hospital readmission
			 reduction program
			 may provide an inaccurate picture of the quality of care provided by
			 hospitals, and has led to the unfair penalization and stigmatization of
			 hospitals
			 serving low-income populations that are, in fact, delivering high-quality
			 health care.

text.#text:
Risk adjustment for socioeconomic status in the Medicare hospital readmission reduction program
			 will improve quality of care, increase accountability for all inpatient
			 hospitals serving Medicare beneficiaries, and further reduce preventable
			 readmissions nationwide.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
should consider the adoption of socioeconomic adjustment
			 methodologies in other quality reporting and pay-for-performance programs
			 under the Medicare program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended—
